abstract.text: Encodes a message and obtains the result in one high-level function call.

A certificate containing a public encryption key for one message recipient, specified as a certificate object (type

of certificate objects. Pass NULL for this parameter if you do not want to encrypt the message.
The object identifier for the encapsulated data in a signed message, in the form of a Core Foundation string—
, for example.
This parameter is optional. If you pass
, the value
is used. (This is the normal encapsulated content type for applications such as S/MIME, which uses it to indicate MIME-encoded content.) You can pass any value that is meaningful to your application.
Specify
if the signed data is to be separate from the message; that is, if the message is_not_ to include the data to be signed. You cannot specify
for this parameter for an encrypted message.
Attribute flags as defined in
. Attributes are optional for signed messages and are not used in other types of CMS messages. The use of attributes is described in section 2.5 of the S/MIME 3.1 specification.
The content that you want to add to the message. The content must conform to the type set in the
parameter (or type
if that function has not been called).
The length of the content being added, in bytes.
On return, points to the encoded message. You must use the
function to free this reference when you are finished using it.
A result code. See
If you use this function, you must include content and you must provide valid non-
input for at least one of the
and

parameters. You can both encrypt and sign a message; however, you cannot use detached content with an encrypted message. If you want to create a message that contains certificates and no other content, you must use the
function instead of this one. To gain more control over the process of encoding a message, call the sequence of functions beginning with the
function instead of this one.

abstract.text: Secure the data your app manages, and control access to your app.
Encodes a message and obtains the result in one high-level function call.
Specifies an object identifier for the encapsulated data of a signed message.
Optional attributes you can add to a signed message.
Evaluate result codes common to many Security framework functions.
A reference to an immutable CFData object.
An untyped "generic" reference to any Core Foundation object.
A raw pointer for accessing untyped data.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
